comment.author: 22919290@N08
comment._content: The pit of that turntable is still in situ, now part of the garden of the old station house at Kilfree. The loco is a typical Ballaghaderreen branch engine, they survived there until closure of the junction and branch in 1963.

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content:
Europe used Steam locomotives later than the US did. Fact is, steam was being replaced by what I lovingly call "diseasel electrics" by the 1940s, E and F type units that lead such legionary passenger trains like the Super Chief, California Zephyr, Rock Island Rocket and 20th Century Limited adopted diseasels just after WWII. Steam was used into the 1950s for mainly small commuter trains and freight. Steam was still seen up into 1960-61 in the US. Many big railroads sold their steamers for scrap, donated some to museums and also to Mexico which continued to operate steam into the late 1960s. 

Some of the mainline English and German steam engines of the 20s-40s were amazing, beautiful things but, for a true steam engine of super strength and performance it's the machines turned out by Baldwin and American locomotive works in the US. :-)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27309380@N06] Diseasel is a great word! May borrow that if you don't mind. And now feel challenged to find photo of "a true steam engine of super strength and performance" to rival your Baldwin and American locomotives!  ;)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] 

Yeah, I was connected with a few model railroaders who had an amazing narrow gauge SN3 scale layout once, the founder of the club lovingly referred to diesel electrics as diseasels. Since they were the very cancer that claimed the lives of all steam locos, I found it a nice play on the word, also fitting. :-)

Run a search of UP Big Boy, UP Challenger and such... huge, HUGE engines! 4-8-8-4's and 4-6-6-4's... articulated locomotives! UP (Union Pacific RR) still operates the Challenger, it's the largest operating steam locomotive in the world!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27309380@N06] Ok, I grant you those Big Boys are pretty impressive...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content: :-) There's a genuine Big Boy at a railroad museum in Pomona California! Funny thing is, I was talking with the curator there and he was saying a school group was there on one occasion and the teacher had to run to the bathroom... The tour guide decided to have some fun with the kids and play a trick on the teacher... The kids ranged between 5-8 years of age... The guide helped them ALL into the massive firebox of that locomotive! It's seriously the size of a banquet hall! :-) The teacher returns and all the kids are gone... then she hears laughter and screams from inside the locomotive! A good laugh was had by all! :-D

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content: Not to over take this conversation, but I'd hand a lot of credit to many lovely, clean, streamlined locomotives of the European continent, the way they seemed to keep them so clean and the lovely colors they wore... Some of the 4-6-4's were elegant with their medium polished green jacketing and black smoke boxes and brass fittings. Tall drivers with long narrow spokes and matching colors to the rest of the engine. The US had a spell of streamlining on steam, it was very easy on the eyes but, the maintenance crews  loathed them! Had to remove so much stuff to get to the parts that needed attention. What some people do for style right? :-)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27309380@N06] I wonder about that sometimes. Apart from the ornate styling, some of our steam trains (even in black and white) look very spruce, while more modern diseasel locomotives look very grubby and oily. Difference between coal and oil?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content:
Not so much a difference between coal and oil so much, it's more of a difference between today and yesterday.

Yesterday, railroad engineers especially in England, France and Germany took pride in their locomotives. Mostly if they were passenger service! The companies then adhered to a strict code of rules and cleanliness was very important for 1st class ticket holders. Regular commuter trains weren't as clean and spotless, however they did receive soap and water ever so oft. Coal burning locomotives were notoriously dirtier than oil burning steam locomotives. Steam locomotives in general are dirty machines because, for the simple fact they require lots of oil for lubrication of vital moving parts and from the exhaust.

Diesel Electrics are dirty because of their exhaust; which is not as noticeable as a rich running steam engine however, today's standards for cleanliness is much lower, nearly nonexistent. Why should a company pay for washing locomotives when they mostly pull dirty freight trains? And the passenger trains do receive a bath ever so oft I'm sure, but the bar has been lowered so far especially here in the States it really is sad.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27309380@N06] That is sad! And thank you for all of your comments - always very interesting to hear from "train people", whether steam or diseasel buffs...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 56911765@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27309380@N06] You maybe interested to know that the Irish were the first to completely eliminate steam from their rails in Europe. By the late 1950s early 60s, Mass dieselisation was done with General Motors Locos built at La Grange Illinois and re-engining previously bought British Locos with GM power plants. The brief flirtation with British Diesels was shortlived as they were found to be notoriuosly under powered and unreliable. Ever since all Locos running on Irish rails have been American. Some of the early GMs only retired a few years ago after nearly 50 years service. Now that's quality.

comment.author: 27309380@N06
comment._content: That is interesting to know! I recall being a child in the early 1980s and seeing old SD's and GP's from the late 50s and early 60s still haling freight on the ol' Santa Fe line along the foothills in the San Gabriel Valley. In fact, it wasn't till just two years ago or less that the UP stared to retire their switcher engines at Colton they've been using since the late 40s!!! They now have all been put to pasture (scraped) and the newer generation is much the same in appearance however obviously the younger more athletic brother. lol

comment.author: 11299198@N07
comment._content:
Good record. There may be another man pushing out of sight at the front. Similar scenes existed in Australia in the 1960s with last use of steam on major systems in the early 70s.

'diseasal' is used in Australia by some who have known the steam era. 'railroad' was exported from the UK to the US along with lots of railway technology in the early 19th century. Then the UK changed to calling them 'railway' instead and the US kept 'railroad'. US Englishes are sometimes a handy reference to UK Englishes of 2 and 3 centuries ago.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 25453448@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27309380@N06] You probably stirred some passions with your challenge to rival the great American steam locomotives.  Difficult to argue with your choice when it comes to absolute size and power rating. But bear in mind that US loading gauge allowed for a much bigger overall size of locos and trains than say Europe, and British loading gauge even on standard gauge is even less than continental Europe's. So allowing for that, and British locomotive engineers' preoccupations with power-to-weight ratios, many Brits would point to the Stanier, Bulleid, Peppercorn, Gresley and Britannia Pacifics for our own best effort on size and power (and grace too).  The French (Chapelon Pacifics?) and Germans have some great claims too. The largest of the steam locos former East Africa and in South Africa (Garratts and Class 25 etc) are hugely impressive considering that they are also narrow gauge.

comment.author: 11299198@N07
comment._content: The USA has a larger loading gauge because their head of government was assassinated. Some non-engineering person decided a dead president's body needed a wider carriage to roam around in state. The infrastructure had to be modified to clear the carriage. The railroads in the USA probably should have a 'John Wilkes Booth day' to celebrate this man's great contribution to the advancement of their industry.

comment.author: 47290943@N03

Incidentally, found lots on the train, The United States here.
